back: The period of sexual maturation, during which a person becomes capable of reproducing.
The time of natural cessation of menstruation; also refers to the biological changes
A type of learning in which one learns to link two or more stimuli and anticipate events.
Learning that certain events occur together. The events may be two stimuli (as in classical conditioning) or a response and its consequences (as in operant conditioning).
A stimulus that unconditionally—naturally and automatically—triggers a response.
An unlearned, naturally occurring response to an unconditioned stimulus (US).
A learned response to a previously neutral (but now conditioned) stimulus (CS).
An originally irrelevant stimulus that, after association with an unconditioned stimulus (US), comes to trigger a conditioned response (CR).
The initial stage in classical conditioning; the phase associating a neutral stimulus with an unconditioned stimulus so that the neutral stimulus comes to elicit a conditioned response.
A form of classical conditioning in which the conditioned stimulus (CS) is presented and removed before the unconditioned stimulus (US) is presented.
A form of classical conditioning in which the conditioned stimulus (CS) and unconditioned stimulus (US) are presented at the same time.
A form of classical conditioning in which the unconditioned stimulus (US) is presented before the conditioned stimulus (CS).

The diminishing of a conditioned response; occurs in classical conditioning when an unconditioned stimulus (US) does not follow a conditioned stimulus (CS); occurs in operant conditioning when a response is no longer reinforced.
The reappearance, after a pause, of an extinguished conditioned response.
The tendency, once a response has been conditioned, for stimuli similar to the conditioned stimulus (CS) to elicit similar responses.
The learned ability to distinguish between a conditioned stimulus (CS) and other irrelevant stimuli.
A procedure in which the conditioned stimulus (CS) in one conditioning experience is paired with a new neutral stimulus, creating a second (often weaker) conditioned stimulus (CS).
A learned aversion to a particular taste or food that occurs after only one pairing of the food with illness.
A form of learning that occurs after only one pairing of the conditioned stimulus (CS) and unconditioned stimulus (US).
The idea that organisms are innately predisposed to form associations between certain stimuli and responses.
A mental connection or relation between two things.
A type of learning in which behavior is strengthened if followed by a reinforcer or diminished if followed by a punisher.
Thorndike's principle that behaviors followed by favorable consequences become more likely, and that behaviors followed by unfavorable consequences become less likely.
In operant conditioning, any event that strengthens the behavior it follows.

Increasing behaviors by presenting positive stimuli, such as food. A positive reinforcer is any stimulus that, when presented after a response, strengthens the response. For example, getting a paycheck for work is an example of positive reinforcement.

Increasing behaviors by stopping or reducing negative stimuli. A negative reinforcer is any stimulus that, when removed after a response, strengthens the response. (Note: negative reinforcement is not punishment.) For example, taking painkillers to end pain is an example of negative reinforcement.
An event that tends to decrease the behavior that it follows.
Adding an aversive stimulus to decrease a behavior. For example, giving a speeding ticket to a driver who exceeds the speed limit.
Removing a rewarding stimulus to decrease a behavior. For example, taking away a child's toy to reduce misbehavior.
A procedure in operant conditioning in which reinforcers guide behavior toward closer and closer approximations of the desired behavior.

The ability to differentiate between different stimuli and respond accordingly. For example, a child may learn to respond to a specific sound that signals the arrival of food, while ignoring other sounds.

In operant conditioning, a stimulus that elicits a response after association with reinforcement (in contrast to related stimuli not associated with reinforcement). For example, a green light may signal that a response will be reinforced, while a red light may signal that it will not.
An innately reinforcing stimulus, such as one that satisfies a biological need. For example, food, water, and warmth are primary reinforcers.

A stimulus that gains its reinforcing power through its association with a primary reinforcer. For example, playing a game on your phone may be a secondary reinforcer because it is associated with the primary reinforcer of fun or entertainment.

A secondary reinforcer that has been associated with a variety of primary reinforcers. For example, money is a generalized reinforcer because it can be exchanged for many different primary reinforcers.
Reinforcing the desired response every time it occurs.
The phenomenon in which behaviors learned under partial reinforcement are more resistant to extinction than those learned under continuous reinforcement.
A pattern that defines how often a desired response will be reinforced.

In operant conditioning, a reinforcement schedule that reinforces a response only after a specified number of responses. For example, a coffee shop may reward you with a free drink after every 10 purchased.

In operant conditioning, a reinforcement schedule that reinforces a response after an unpredictable number of responses. For example, slot machines reward gamblers after a varying number of responses.

In operant conditioning, a reinforcement schedule that reinforces a response only after a specified time has elapsed. For example, people check more frequently for the mail as the delivery time approaches.
In operant conditioning, a reinforcement schedule that reinforces a response at unpredictable time intervals. For example, checking for a Facebook message or email.
The tendency of learned behavior to gradually revert to biologically predisposed patterns.
The process of observing and imitating a specific behavior. Also known as vicarious learning.
The theory that we learn social behavior by observing and imitating and by being rewarded or punished.
Learning that occurs but is not apparent until there is an incentive to demonstrate it.
A mental representation of the layout of one's environment. For example, after exploring a maze, rats act as if they have learned a cognitive map of it.
A sudden realization of a problem's solution; contrasts with strategy-based solutions.
